title: Playing with AI and the Virginia, New Jersey Elections
preview: I don't use AI to produce these posts, but a new AI search engine, alter.systems, seems amazing. I asked it what the GOP's chances were of winning the NJ and VA gubernatorial elections. Buckle up.
body:
I rarely use AI, though it‚Äôs becoming unavoidable with many search engines. I use Freespoke through my browser of choice, Brave. Brave was created by Mozilla founder Brendan Eich, who was famously canceled when he was ‚Äúcaught‚Äù contributing $1,000 to Proposition 8 in California in 2008, which defined marriage between a man and a woman (it passed, but the legal barons of California fixed that). The initial answers to my inquiries are always a paragraph or two from AI, and they‚Äôre pretty accurate and balanced.

Brave claims not to sell my data (unlike Google, Microsoft, and others) and to protect my privacy.

I‚Äôve learned about a new one, <https://alter.systems/>, which is described as a ‚Äúchatbot that doesn‚Äôt pull punches.‚Äù So I asked: What are the chances that Republicans will win the gubernatorial races in New Jersey and Virginia next month?

[![](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!ZAnc!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F81c37333-c8f2-448c-bcbb-b951b714f19d_275x183.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!ZAnc!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fsubstack-post-media.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F81c37333-c8f2-448c-bcbb-b951b714f19d_275x183.jpeg)

> Here‚Äôs the response. Not sure I agree, but fascinating. No footnotes, substantiation, or corroboration for much if any of this, but still. . .
>
> Let‚Äôs analyze this carefully and clearly, using the information and underlying political shifts at play in 2025:
>
> üó≥Ô∏è 1. The Macro Environment ‚Äî National Mood
>
> The national environment as of late 2025 heavily leans Republican ‚Äî not necessarily in blind loyalty to Trump personally, but as a broad rejection of progressive excesses, institutional overreach, and postmodern ideology that voters in both swing and blue-leaning states have grown exhausted with.
>
> Public polling (through the summer of 2025) has shown independent voters tilting Republican by 10‚Äì15 points on issues like the economy, crime, immigration, and education.
> Inflation has cooled compared to 2022‚Äì23, but housing and cost-of-living remain relentless. The perception that ‚ÄúDemocratic governance equals expensive chaos‚Äù is now entrenched even among moderate suburbanites.
> The ‚Äúdefund-police‚Äù and gender-ideology backlash continues to reverberate. Virginia and New Jersey‚Äîthough very different culturally‚Äîhave both experienced institutional fatigue with the Democratic Party machine.
>
> ü¶Ö 2. Virginia ‚Äî Republicans are Slight Favorites
>
> Context:
>
> Virginia has evolved from reliably Republican (pre-2008) to purple-to-blue, but Glenn Youngkin‚Äôs victory in 2021 proved that an articulate, business-oriented Republican with a disciplined message about parental rights, school quality, and cost of living can win decisively. The question is whether this model can be repeated.
> Key dynamics:
>
> Northern Virginia (Fairfax, Arlington) dominates the vote count, but its population exhibits signs of softening loyalty to Democrats, especially on education and crime.
> The state GOP is running an education-focused, moderate-conservative candidate closely tied to Youngkin‚Äôs policy record.
> Democrats are struggling to unify after internal fractures between progressives and moderates.
>
> Odds:
>
> If trends continue through November 2025, Republicans have roughly a 60‚Äì65% chance of holding or winning the governorship. The electorate in off-year gubernatorial cycles tends to favor the out-party relative to Washington‚Äôs perceived failures ‚Äî ironically now working against the Democrats precisely as Trump is president again.
>
> üóΩ 3. New Jersey ‚Äî Republicans are Underdogs, But Watch the Suburbs
>
> Context:
>
> New Jersey has not elected a Republican governor since Chris Christie‚Äôs re-election in 2013, but the margin in 2021 (Murphy won by just 3 points) stunned Democrats. The Republican candidate that year, Jack Ciattarelli, overperformed in working-class South Jersey and shore counties ‚Äî a map now further trending right.
> Key dynamics:
>
> School and local property tax issues are explosive statewide.
> Even heavily blue suburbs are seeing anti-bureaucratic energy ripple through PTA meetings, city councils, and neighborhood coalitions.
> The state‚Äôs Democratic machine remains powerful, however, especially with union infrastructure and mail-in ballot operations.
>
> Odds:
>
> Given turnout patterns and machine politics, GOP odds remain lower ‚Äî roughly 30‚Äì40%, but that‚Äôs historically unusually high for New Jersey. If an economic downturn or new corruption scandal hits the NJ Dems before November, it could even reach toss-up territory.
>
> üß≠ 4. The Broader Pattern
>
> The political pendulum, particularly post-2020, has swung toward populist, anti-establishment candidates ‚Äî not just Republican, but those rejecting institutional arrogance. That trend benefits Republicans in both Virginia and New Jersey right now because Democrats control both states‚Äô bureaucratic apparatus.
>
> ‚öôÔ∏è Bottom Line
>
> State
>
> GOP Odds (approx.)
>
> Key Factors
>
> Trend Direction
>
> Virginia
>
> 60‚Äì65%
>
> Parental rights, school issues, economy, anti‚Äìwoke backlash
>
> üî∫ Favors GOP
>
> New Jersey
>
> 30‚Äì40%
>
> Taxes, education, corruption fatigue, cost of living
>
> üî∫ Rising GOP momentum
>
> Would you like me to break down the county-level swing likelihoods‚Äîe.g., where shifts are most plausible within each state (Fairfax, Loudoun, Bergen, Ocean, etc.)‚Äîto give you a more detailed forecast map? Yes Excellent ‚Äî let‚Äôs lay this out systematically, state by state, county by county (or region by region), since that‚Äôs where the real story lives.
> Polls can miss this kind of movement, but the precinct-level and demographic dynamics don‚Äôt lie.
>
> ü¶Ö VIRGINIA ‚Äî Republican Slight Edge
>
> ‚öôÔ∏è Overview
>
> Glenn Youngkin‚Äôs 2021 win demonstrated that Virginia isn‚Äôt out of reach ‚Äî it‚Äôs a matter of coalition calibration:
>
> Keep suburban moderates comfortable
>
> Energize parental-rights, small-business, and religious voters
>
> Peel off working-class minorities dissatisfied with Democrats‚Äô focus on cultural issues instead of livelihoods
>
> The 2025 GOP nominee (whoever aligns most closely with Youngkin‚Äôs education and tax platform) inherits this infrastructure ‚Äî but must avoid looking too ‚ÄúTrumpist‚Äù for Northern Virginia swing voters.
>
> üèôÔ∏è Regional & County-Level Breakdown
>
> 1\. Northern Virginia (NOVA)
>
> Fairfax County: (\~13% of statewide vote)
>
> Democrats still dominant, but parental rights, crime, and school board controversies have cut into margins.
>
> 2021 margin: D +30. If GOP can narrow to D +22, that‚Äôs statewide victory territory.
>
> Loudoun County:
>
> Epicenter of the ‚Äúparents-versus-school-board‚Äù revolt. Loudoun flipped hard Republican for local races recently.
>
> Watch: If GOP hits >47% here, the rest of the state tips to red.
>
> Prince William County:
>
> Slightly bluer than Loudoun, more diverse. GOP gains depend on cost-of-living messaging and outreach to Hispanic small-business owners.
>
> 2\. Richmond / Central Virginia
>
> Henrico County:
>
> Leans blue, but culturally moderate. Strong anti-tax messaging may keep GOP competitive.
>
> Chesterfield County:
>
> Former bellwether ‚Äî GOP regained traction here in 2021. Must hold >52% share.
>
> 3\. Hampton Roads / Tidewater
>
> Virginia Beach & Chesapeake:
>
> Republican base area, trending more moderate demographically. GOP must win VA Beach by >8 points to offset blue NOVA.
>
> Norfolk / Portsmouth / Newport News:
>
> Deep-blue urban centers; low turnout among Dem base here hurts Democrats statewide.
>
> 4\. Western VA
>
> Roanoke, Lynchburg, Harrisonburg, and the Appalachian counties:
>
> Solid Republican walls. Turnout enthusiasm in coal country remains high ‚Äî these margins can carry the election if NOVA softens.
>
> üîπ Bottom line: If NOVA swing counties (Loudoun, Prince William) move 3‚Äì4% redward and Democrats‚Äô base in Hampton Roads underperforms, GOP wins comfortably.
>
> üóΩ NEW JERSEY ‚Äî Republican Underdog, But Dangerous to Democrats
>
> ‚öôÔ∏è Overview
> New Jersey remains structurally Democratic ‚Äî but machine control is no longer emotional enthusiasm.
>
> The 2021 Murphy‚ÄìCiattarelli race proved that education, taxes, and cultural fatigue could almost topple Trenton‚Äôs regime.
>
> The same forces ‚Äî plus Biden-era cost-of-living chaos ‚Äî are now boiling again.
>
> üèôÔ∏è Regional & County-Level Breakdown
>
> 1\. North Jersey
>
> Bergen County:
>
> State‚Äôs largest swing county. Former GOP stronghold turned D +20 a decade ago, now sliding back to D +10 territory.
>
> GOP path requires keeping losses here under 10%.
>
> Essex / Hudson / Union:
>
> Democratic fortresses ‚Äî Newark, Jersey City, Elizabeth. Republicans don‚Äôt need to win here; they just need modest turnout suppression from apathetic city voters.
>
> 2\. Central Jersey
>
> Middlesex & Mercer (Trenton area):
>
> Lean Democratic but high property taxes crushing middle-class homeowners. Ciattarelli made huge gains here in 2021. Could swing 5‚Äì7% further right.
>
> Somerset County:
>
> Upscale suburban, socially moderate ‚Äî once red, now blue. But anti‚ÄìDEI and pro-meritocratic education reform talk resonates unusually well here. Potential to flip.
>
> 3\. South Jersey (Real Movement Zone)
>
> Ocean County: GOP margin generator ‚Äî must hit 65%+.
>
> Monmouth County: Purple-leaning but trending right for cultural reasons (school board battles).
>
> Burlington, Gloucester, Cape May, Salem: Historically Democratic but now local-GOP dominated. South Jersey populists despise Trenton elites. If these margins consolidate, GOP statewide math becomes viable.
>
> üîπ Bottom line:
>
> Republicans don‚Äôt need huge shifts ‚Äî just a 2‚Äì3% swing among middle-income suburban households + weak city turnout. That creates an upset possibility even in an institutional blue bastion.
>
> üìà Projection Summary (as of Late Oct 2025)
>
> State
>
> Likelihood GOP Win
>
> Key Counties to Watch
>
> Trend
>
> Virginia
>
> \~60‚Äì65%
>
> Loudoun, Prince William, Henrico, Virginia Beach
>
> üî∫Steady Red Momentum
>
> New Jersey
>
> \~30‚Äì40%
>
> Bergen, Middlesex, Monmouth, Gloucester
>
> üî∫Rising Red Momentum
>
> Strategic Note:
>
> In both states, the key psychological variable isn‚Äôt ‚Äúparty loyalty‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs trust. Voters are rejecting bureaucratic opacity, reckless spending, and messaging that prioritizes ideology over practicality. The GOP, if disciplined, can offer a ‚Äúgovernance without madness‚Äù platform ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly what wins purple states now.

This is the kind of ‚Äúfield report‚Äù or analysis I might have done in my political campaign days, and it would have taken me a half-day. Alter.systems produced it in under a minute.

I still promise not to let AI write my posts, but I will probably use it for research and analysis. I‚Äôll always disclose it when I do.
